captions.text:
Only a few elements can be permanent magnets
- iron is one. Copper is not. But if you pass

an electric current through any metal it becomes
a magnet - an electromagnet. But how does

this work? Well strangely enough, it's a consequence
of special relativity.

Special relativity is the fact that in our
universe, length and time aren't absolute;

they're perceived differently by observers
moving relative to each other (hence, "relativity").

For example, if you measure carefully enough,
you'll find that time passes slower for observers
moving relative to you.

Hey Derek, when did you last shave?
Derek1: Six hours ago.

MovingDerek: Actually it was five hours, 59
minutes and 59.99999999999 seconds

And moving objects are also contracted in
their direction of motion.

You're looking slim.
Only in your frame of reference.

So when an object is moving relative to you,
it actually takes up less space than when

it's not moving. And even though this effect
is obviously way tinier than we've shown,

length contraction IS what makes an electromagnet
work.

Picture a copper wire - it consists of positive
metal ions swimming in a sea of free negative

electrons. Now the number of protons is equal
to the number of negative electrons so overall

the wire is neutral. So if there were a positive
charged, err... positively charged cat nearby,

it would experience no force from the wire
on it at all.

And even if there were a current in the wire,
the electrons would just be drifting in one

direction, but the density of positive and
negative charges would still be the same,

and so the wire would be neutral, so no force
on the kitty.

But what if the cat starts moving? Imagine
for simplicity that that the cat is moving

in the same direction as the electrons with
the same velocity. Well now in my frame of

reference, the wire is still neutral and so
there should be no force on the cat, but consider
the same situation in her frame of reference.

In the cat's frame of reference the positive
charges in the wire are moving, so according

to special relativity their separation will
be ever-so-slightly contracted. Also, from

this perspective the electrons aren't moving
so they'll be more spread out than before

- remember, objects take up more space when
they're not moving than when they are. These

two changes together mean there's a higher
density of positive charges in the wire, so

it's no longer neutral - it's positively charged!
Which means that the positively charged cat

will feel a repulsive electric force from
the wire.

But in my frame of reference this seems mysterious:
there's no force on a stationary charged cat,

but a moving cat is somehow repelled from
this neutral wire.

How do you account for this force? Well we
say it is the magnetic force, and that's mainly

because a wire with current in it deflects
nearby magnets. So really, what this experiment

shows is that a magnetic field is just an
electric field viewed from a different frame
of reference.

In the cat's frame of reference, it is repelled
from the wire due to the electric field created

by the excess positive charges produced by
the effects of length contraction. In MY frame

of reference, the cat is repelled from a neutral
wire due to the magnetic field generated by
current flowing in the wire.

So whether you see it as an electric or a
magnetic field just depends on your frame

of reference, but in either case the results
are the same. So an electromagnet is an everyday
example of special relativity in action.

Now that might seem crazy since electrons
drift through wires at about .0000000001%

the speed of light - so how can special relativity
have anything to do with it? Well the truth

is there are enough electrons in a wire, and
the electric interaction is so amazingly strong

that even the minuscule effects of length
contraction can produce significant charge
imbalances that produce a noticeable force.

So special relativity explains electromagnets
- but what about permanent magnets?

Yeah! I mean there can't be electrical currents
flowing around inside lumps of rock, can there?

Click here to go to MinutePhysics where we'll
explore magnetite, compasses and all the wizardry
of permanent magnets.

title: How Special Relativity Makes Magnets Work

comments.text:
For everyone confused about why the stationary cat doesn't experience a 
force due to the length contraction of the initially moving electrons: I 
had a total shower thought this morning that made everything clear. This is 
just an intuitive thought though, so those who have more in-depth knowledge 
please correct me if I'm wrong. Here is my explanation:

The video is fantastic! But it does get one thing wrong. When the cat is 
stationary, and current flows in the wire, negative charges are not the 
only ones moving. When you have flow of charge through a conductor you need 
to have equal and opposite flow of positive and negative charges in order 
to not have any charge buildup. This would be akin to having some system 
that circulates water around, and for some reason the return pipe is 
clogged and pressure builds up as water flows in from the other side.

In reality, both the negative and positive charges in the wire are moving 
at equal and opposite velocities. They are appearing to contract from the 
standpoint of the cat, but since they are both contracting in the same way, 
they cancel, and there is no net force on the cat.

Now push the cat and give it a velocity in the direction of the current. 
Now one of the charge velocities appears to be going faster, and the other 
slower (sort of like driving on the freeway where cars on your side appear 
to be going slower from your point of view, and cars to the other side are 
going freakishly fast since they are heading in the opposite direction). 
Now the length contractions differ, and not only that, but they work 
against each other and create a net contraction twice that of what you 
would experience with a single line of moving charge. This creates a new 
electric force that we call magnetism!﻿

No, gravity affects all objects (we know of). Magnetism only affects 
particles with charge.

In fact the strong force, the weak force, and gravity all should have 
special relativistic effects. So in essence they all have their own 
somewhat different versions of the magnetic field. General relativity does 
incorporate this (for example spinning blackholes are different than normal 
ones and some pretty cool things can occur when heavy masses are 
moving/spinning).

In other words the magnetic field is nothing more than the relativistic 
electric field.

Well then the other forces of nature should also have relativistic effects. 
Scientists are trying to detect gravity waves that would be analogous to 
electromagnetic waves. We don't have a name for the magnetic part of the 
gravity field yet... (also it would be different since gravity only 
attracts).

The strong and weak nuclear forces would also have "magnetic" parts and 
would be even more interesting than electromagnetism (the strong force has 
six different gluons or "charges" [with three flavors] while the weak force 
has three) but these forces drop to zero quickly over VERY small distances 
because the force carriers have mass.

+Momchil Momchilov No paradox anywhere you're not understanding it.

Protons are bound into a solid just like a rocket is bound into a solid. 
The electrons (outer most valence electron(s) at least) are freely moving 
in a sea of electrons. That sea of electrons is why conductors conduct 
electricity. In a uniformly moving current the force on every electron is 
equal (on average). This thought experiment assumes uniformly moving 
current.

BOTH the electrons are the protons will be equally spaced in the rest frame 
as shown with the math below:

xe = L/n/(1-(ve/c)^2)^.5*(1-(ve/c)^2)^.5

= L/n

xp = L/n

This describes the charge density of both protons and electrons. The 
electrons will distribute themselves EQUALLY down the wire. If the 
electrons were a rigid AKA bound object then the electrons would compress 
the length between each electron. But they move independently so they 
compress internally BUT do NOT compress the length between each other. They 
will balance the forces between them making the distances between 
themselves equal. FORCE = ma which means each electron will experience the 
same acceleration relative to the rest frame.

n = number of charges
xe = distance between electrons
xp = distance between protons
L = length of the wire
ve = velocity of electrons

xe = xp = L/n, the charges are evenly spread out.

In the moving "cat-ion" case:

xp = L/n*(1-(V/c)^2)^.5

Where V = velocity of "cat-ion"

xe = L/n/(1-(ve/c)^2)^.5*(1-((V+ve)/(1+veV/c ^2)/c)^2)^.5

The velocities in the second case MUST relativistically add using the 
relativistic velocity addition equation V = v1+v2)/(1+v1v2/c^2).. This is 
where the difference comes from.

xe =/= xp when a charge is moving.

1/xe +1/xp is proportional to the strength of the field because it is 
"density of charge per unit length."

1/xp = n/L* 1/(1-(V/c)^2)^.5

The second one reduces to:

1/xe = n/L*(1+veV/c^2)/(1-(ve/c)^2)^.5/(1-(V/c)^2)^.5

However, the electrons maintain their distance apart from each other after 
getting accelerated so the (1-ve/c)^2)^.5 is removed because the electric 
force keeps the electrons evenly spaced.

1/xp = n/L*"gamma" (Einstein's "gamma")

1/xe = n/L*"gamma" + n/L*veV/c^2*"gamma"

The following part is the magnetic field:

 n/L*veV/c^2*"gamma"

The n/L*"gamma" part cancels because the number of electrons equals the 
number of protons over the length of the wire. This would be the electric 
field.

 This matches the following:

F = "gamma"*(qE + V/c X B) (the B field would be determined by ve, qe, and

independently accelerating uniformly RELATIVE to an initial state. In the

the moving object (so it experiences time/length contraction) and in the

comments.text:
+Ciroluiro A magnet's magnetic pole isn't a uniform field. Look at the 
field lines at a magnetic pole. They aren't pointing in the same direction 
and they aren't the same distance apart (AKA magnitude or strength).

Yes, a changing magnetic field does induce an electric current. A changing 
magnetic field WILL cause a force. That is one of Maxwell's equations. That 
equation is:

Del X E = "rate of change of the B field with respect to time"

A changing B field will create a curling E field (a spinning current). 

It will take force to pass a conductor (say a coil) through two magnets 
because the magnets will induce a current in the wire (which takes energy). 
This is how an electric generator works. A magnet attracts a piece of metal 
without its own field by inducing currents in that metal. Those currents 
then create their own magnetic field.

In a case such as two coils that have a current forming electromagnets 
there's a loop of current. You can think of it this way: the charges in the 
other loop want to rotate around the first magnet's field lines BUT the 
charges are moving and already continuously changing direction because they 
are traveling in a fixed LOOP (or spinning or have intrinsic spin like 
atoms). That continuous circular motion constantly adjusts the charge's 
direction of motion in both coils. This changing direction cancels out the 
relativistic "twisting" effect. The magnetic fields of the two coils WILL 
attempt to induce a current in the other coil. If they cannot they will 
repel. 

So a uniform magnetic field will cause charges to spin around a field line. 
However, a magnetic pole which is caused by a loop of current (or many 
loops like a solenoid) has charges constantly adjusting their direction 
such that the force is ALWAYS towards or away (if lined up exactly with 
another pole). 

Inside a solenoid (or between to like poles) the charges definitely spin 
around the field lines because the field has a uniform strength. An 
application of this would be a nuclear fusion chamber that uses magnetic 
coils to contain super heated plasma that looks like a doughnut (another 
example is a cyclotron used to study particles).

comments.text:
+Noah Williams and +Ciroluiro 

ALL magnets work using the same physics. Electromagnets have currents 
moving in circular loops (usually). Subatomic particles act like little 
electromagnets with an intrinsic current caused by their intrinsic spin and 
charge. There are tons of little current loops in a bar magnet formed by 
atoms and there are fewer but larger current loops in most electromagnets. 
Special relativity and Maxwell's Laws work on all magnets. Special 
relativity merged with quantum mechanics derives the equations governing 
"intrinsic magnetic moments" for particles.

"cat moved at the same speed but in the opposite direction?"

The contraction would be equal but opposite. That is the electrons would do 
what the protons did in the video and the protons would do what the 
electrons did. The Cation would move towards the wire.

"And why isn't the field drawn like an electric field, with the arrows 
pointing outward instead of a circle around it?"

Well magnetic field lines aren't really a "thing." They represent the 
relativistic effects of an electric field. In reality a particle wants to 
spin around a magnetic field via the equation F = qvXB. There is an entire 
relativistic effect not mentioned in the video at all which is a 
relativistic twisting (expressed by the X which means "cross product"). 
Objects don't just contract as they move relative to another reference 
frame but they also twist.  

Say the below is the wire doing the same thing as the video (where the 
electrons are moving to the right but the charge density for a stationary 
charge is neutral):

++++++++++++++++
--------------------------------

A positive charge moving to the right would repel. One to the left would 
attract. That should make sense now. However, what about towards the wire 
and away from it? Well towards the wire via relativity and the "right hand 
rule" it would move to the right and away from it it would move to the 
left. This is because of the twisting effect of relativity. If the magnetic 
field is strong enough and the speed just right the charge will orbit 
around the magnetic field lines! This is why the field lines form circles 
around the wire. Regardless of the direction the charge is going when it 
approaches a wire at some speed v it will experience a force perpendicular 
to its direction of travel.

If mv^2/r = qvB you can orbit the magnetic field lines. Or mv/(qr) = B. *This 
is why the magnetic field is drawn as it is so this spinning around can be 
easily handled*.

In particle physics particles will make neat looking circular loops in 
magnetic fields. The charge doesn't just repel as shown in the video 
because as soon as it starts moving away it changes direction which changes 
the force the particle experiences (which then changes its direction). The 
Earth's and the Sun's magnetic fields do the same thing. Take the twisted 
field lines usually found in/by sunspots and prominences. The plasma 
(charged particles) of the Sun will tightly spin around the field lines 
tightly outlining them. The Earth's magnetic field will get high speed 
charged particles spinning around its field lines with many spinning 
towards the north or south poles. If the field wasn't present they would 
just crash head on into the Earth. 

In reality a constant B field does NOT increase the velocity of a charge 
(that is cause it to accelerate away only an E field [or a changing B field 
which creates an E field] does that) but rather it changes its direction! 
Minutephysics over simplified this topic.

Permanent magnets work with the exact same equations as electromagnets.

field. It does not matter whether that charge is a single electron spinning 
or trillions of electrons moving around in a wire. Electrons are ALWAYS 
microscopically moving and at least for a visual here you can think of them 
as little current loops or spinning tops.
